reviewText:
First things first: Sachi a cute. Ignore the haters.

Hitomebore is a love story visual novel that, from my understanding, was made mostly by one person. Originally released last year at COMITIA 107, the Steam version comes with improved CGs and an English translation by Sekai Project. Hitomebore runs on Renpy, which is fairly uncommon for a Japanese production despite its status as the go-to visual novel framework in the West, so that's quite interesting.

The game's strongest point (by a considerable margin) is its creepy look. There is a short animated clip whenever the chapter changes. Unfortunately, like so many other visual novels, the game runs natively in a low, 4:3 resolution.

Music is MIDI-tier at times, but not unpleasant to listen to. I kind of like the main theme in fact, but it's not something I'd listen to outside of the game.

Story is where it all falls apart, both in terms of length and writing quality. Without spoiling anything, let's just say that the game never takes full advantage of its fairly unique theme of having a girl with one eye. You could replace it with a different condition without having to rewrite much of the story, which by the way is high school drama that we all have seen a thousand times before. Highlights are the scene where the MC feeds Sachi, and the scenes where he touches her scars. You will be getting about 2-3 hours of story, which for its price tag is quite short.

For 10 bucks I can't recommend it due to its length and writing, but since Sachi is such a likeable character and the game is an indie product, I can't regret spending 10 bucks on it either.

reviewText:
When you look past the strange heroine, Love at First Sight is a pretty straightforward high school romance VN. There's no ero in the game itself, but it has a few ero-guro undertones that might be off-putting for some. Even so, there's a certain soft grace to it all; Ray-K's painterly style brings warmth and tenderness to every scene, catching the restrained giddiness of young love in a way that might be lost with cleaner, flatter designs. It is, in a word, comfy.

The characters are likeable, for the most part, with Sachi standing head and shoulders over any run-of-the-mill moeblob love interest. She invites sympathy and the urge to protect, but her vulnerability never really grates. The music doesn't stand out by any means, but its gentleness supports the cozy atmosphere well.

There is very little beyond the story's single path, unfortunately — about two hours of content in all. Even the most casual reader will chew through it quickly, and depending on their tastes, they'll probably be left wanting more. It's perhaps not enough to warrant the full $10. But if it's on sale and you have five bucks to spare, time spent on crisp autumn back-streets with a cute cyclops girl is time well invested.

Admittedly, I might be biased here; that wide, bottomless eye will ease open your chest and grope the scars. But isn't that the point?

Pick this up if you enjoy cutely macabre aesthetics, monster girls, romance, and if you see it on sale.

---
+ Cute monster girl heroine
+ Cozy autumn setting
+ Warm, comfy art style
+ The extra features serve as a fun little epilogue and development backstory
+ When you're done with the story and extras, check the creator's Pixiv for a bit more

- Only one story path
- That one path is a little bare-bones and straightforward
- At 2-3 hours, the VN is extremely short — perhaps too short to justify a $10 price tag

reviewText:
Love At First Sight is the story of a boy who meets a girl who doesn't look “normal”, and how they slowly come to know and then love each other.
Being a fan of anime I am used to eyes so big that they would shame the average Seville orange, but this time we are talking melon size. Surely there can't any room left in that head for a brain? Ah, whatever. The only thing more bizarre is her choice in clothes. A melon wrapped in pink meringue springs to mind.
The story is quite cute, but I found something slightly disturbing about it. It's a very typical Japanese anime relationship that develops very slowly and is really gentle. All good so far. It tries to deal with the issues of a person who doesn't conform to norms…. but you get the idea that the female protagonist was made that way to appeal to the small number of males who find solace in the belief that if normal girls don't like them then maybe they can find an abnormal one that will.  Maybe I am being too harsh, but I have never really liked the overly demure female characters that seem fairly popular with Otakus. The novel goes so far to refer to the player as the protagonist at several points in the game, making it very clear who this game is aimed at.
In short, I think this novel will appeal to a niche market. It is very well produced, the illustrations are just fine, and while some will find the story very cute, others will be perplexed by it. I do recommend it, but with a lot of reservation.

reviewText:
Love at First Sight isn't very good. I'll start with that. The game's story is nothing to write home about. It's a boring, standard, high-school romance. Now, sure, there's nothing wrong with a clichéd story, but if a story's going to be cliché, it needs to make up for it in some other area.

Okay, so if the story's cliché, how about the characters? Well, they're just as two-dimensional as the story. The protagonist is a VN protagonist. He's 'nice,' kind of, and that is all there is to him. The cyclops girl, Sachi, is the shy one who doesn't have any friends. The supporting cast is comprised of the loud one and the cynical one. That's all I remember about them. The antagonist is 'the bully', who I'm convinced only exists to justify the writer ham-fisting his fetish for scars into the game.

Did I mention that the author really likes scars? Because there are at least three different scenes in the game where the protagonist touches Sachi's scars. Each scene is written with the sort of lurid prose you see when you know that the writer is masturbating furiously to what they're writing.

Moving away from the author's fetishes, let's talk about the soundtrack. It's even worse than the story. Every song is made using bad MIDI instruments that don't mesh well. The songs themselves have no sense of what constitutes a good melody or harmony, leaving a soundtrack that manages to almost be mediocre at its very best.

The art's interesting enough, it has a decent, sketch-like aesthetic, but I question if that's intentional or just a result of the fact that the game was made in the space of two months by a single guy.

Now, length: The game is an hour and a half long. It's an appropriate length for what it is, but certainly not worth the ten dollars it's charging.

All in all, this game is really not very good and there are so many things better than this that you could be spending your money on. Hell, there are visual novels better (and longer) than this at the same price point or lower on Steam right now.

tl;dr: If you really, really like cyclops girls, amateurish storytelling, and scars, I won't stop you from buying this. For everyone else, give it a pass.

Despite the time-limited development of 2 months of serious work, and the 2-man dev team of Ray-Kbys and kyou1110 (kyou helping with most of the music, Ray-K doing everything else), this visual novel manages to produce a touching-yet-refreshing story, with a cast of 6 underused-stereotype characters and more than decent writing in plot and character development. As a personal fan of Ray-Kbys' artwork, this piece displays some of his most inspired 2-D animations, which are short, but are used to astounding effect. This being a fairly short piece (I finished all content within 5 hours), hearing that this may have been a full-blown dating sim game with a branching story (if Ray-K hadn't procrastinated until 2 moths before) raises my hopes that Ray-Kbys may try his more determined hand at a full-blown dating sim one day.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes vanilla romance visual novels, people who like cute anime games, people who like unique artwork, people who are into injury/cyclops girls/sickeningly sweet romance fetishes, and just people with good humor, as this VN displays all these qualities and more. Just enough character development is placed into the story to entice veteran 2D romance enthusiasts and critics of the genre alike. As an added benefit, the cards for this game sell for nearly as much as the game itself on 50% off atm, assuming you don't wish to collect them for the rare adorable-cyclops-girl Steam backgrounds, so buy away!

Well worth $5, still worth $10 for VN enthusiasts. You're supporting an excellent and unique artist, after all.

reviewText:
For a game made in 2 months this is fairly impressive, but for a game on Steam with an asking price of  $10 it is very underwhelming.

I understand the constraints the dev was under to get this game ready in time for a con that he wanted to sell it at, but there is no reason why afterwards, when the pressure was gone, that he couldn't have revisited the title and expanded upon it before putting it onto a larger market, such as Steam.

As it stands the story is decent, but nothing spectacular. More than once there were times you would expect there to be more shown, but he just ends up alluding to events and then skipping right over them (presumably cuts made to get the game done on time). The story with the main antagonist ended in a very unsatisfactory manner, though I will refrain from expanding on that any further to avoid spoilers. Most of the side characters also didn't really get as much time as I would have liked in order to get to know them better. Also -- unless you share in some of the creator's fetishes for things like injuries -- a lot of the dialog will seem forced, weird or unnecessary as they are mainly tacked on to serve his own indulgences. Last nitpick about the story is that, while this is tagged as a visual novel, it would be more accurate to call it a kinetic novel due to the linear nature of the story and lack of any choices along the way.

The art style is nice and the main selling point that drew me to this title. Though as with everything else about this game, it would have been nice to of had more of it, for instance there was very little by way of CG stills/cutscenes. However, it does have a far more coherent and enjoyable aesthetic than most other amateur VN offerings and deserves a fair bit of praise for that alone.

Sound was just so-so. Some of the music could use a bit of work, there were some grating off key notes thrown in inexpertly throughout a few of the tracks that detracted from my enjoyment, but otherwise the soundtrack was ok and fit the story well enough.

Overall, I enjoyed it, but the creator really should have came back and put another 2-4 months into this before bring it to Steam, then this would have been well worth the asking price and a highly recommended title for those who enjoy quirky VNs. But as it stands I can't recommend it unless you find it on a pretty decent sale, as you just wont get your money's worth otherwise.

reviewText: Short but a very sweet

Love at First Sight is a simple romance visual novel, and its a very adorable one at that. While it may not have the action, cast, or production budget of bigger name VNs, I actually prefer small and simple ones like this. The whole thing is over in about two to three hours, but it manages to tell its story well enough.
Starting with the positives of the game, the between-chapter animations are adorable. The very first time I saw one I let out an audible squeal that I am not ashamed of. Theyre simple but well executed in ways that will make your heart melt. Continuing with the uguu-train, Sachi herself is a very adorable love interest and easily one of my favorites, even out of bigger name VNs that Ive played. Although her character isnt anything new, the person who made the game knew what they were doing and how to use Sachi for maximum effectiveness. I would take one Sachi over a hundred Sakura Matous any day.
The supporting cast of the VN is also very enjoyable, however scarse they are. There is only six named characters in the entire VN, and while that is a disappointing thing, the cahracters are all likeable enough that you wont even care. Akemi and her explosively cheerful attitude and Tomo's indifference play off of each other like poetry, and I really enjoy seeing characters like them. As stated before, Sachi is one of my favorite VN characters. She makes my heart sing. The main character, Mamoru is bland as white bread, but that is of course to be expected of a VN protag so that the reader can realte more. If he went around kicking puppies, then I dont think many people could relate.
Unfortunately after the good must come the bad, and Ill start with the worst offender that youll be dealing with the whole game: The music is terrible. It sounds like a cheap MIDI on a fifteen second loop. I understand that the game was made by a single person, and I understand that you might not be an author AND a composer, but its still a negative.
The plot is a standard VN highschool plot: Boy transfers in, boy has small or nonexistant group of friends, finds outcast girl, helps her come out of her shell, kiss kiss fall in love, and then help her overcome her main issue in the story. If youre expecting twists and turns, then you are a fool. While the plot and character archetypes are all very known by this point, I do have to mention that they are all well done, especially for how long the VN is.
For the praise I gave Akemi earlier, I must tack on some sins as well. The game doesnt allow her to be as expressive as she is due to the limited facial expressions and poses that it provides. This doesnt detract from her character of my enjoyment of the VN, but it does leave me wanting more out of her that I will be unable to have.

Strongly recommend this. Short. simple and sweet. Love at First Sight is, as you all know, about a girl with one eye and an average student who fall in love. Music is pretty average, but if you take the time to go through the extras you'll know why, this game was made in under two months, which makes me love it even more actually. Art style is absolutely amazing, fell in love with it at first sight, heh. Sweet, unusual and heartwarming. I will try to keep this completely spoiler-free, which means I will probably not talk much about it story-wise.

- Story and Characters

You must have noticed that the heroine of this VN isn't your mainstream moe heroine, she's way more cute and interesting. I won't say anything else about her, because I found out that actually getting to know her through the story is what made this such a great experience for me.

The story is short and the cast small, but I loved every part of it, even the slightly strange ones.
You have two very likeable characters as your support casting, who are not just filling up the space, but instead have their own things going on. Their personalities are also built very clear, so that the way they act and interact with you and the other characters feels very natural.

Also, don't forget to check the Extras after you finish. There are a few extra scenes there.

- VN

Now, for the technical stuff.
This is a linear visual novel with a single route. Which means it's more like a digital book than a game itself, and to be fair most visual novels are exactly that. I would say the greatest selling point of this kind of product is that you get an experience similar to those you would get from reading books, comics or manga, but with the extras allowed by the medium used to convey the story.

A story can be conveyed in many different forms. A linear visual novel allows you to attach shifting scenes to every piece of dialogue, with characters in different poses over backgrounds. You are also allowed to place pictures drawn for special events, and in this game's case, even small cutscenes for every chapter title. And finally, wrap it all up with music fitting for every moment. This is an experience that is most close to reading a novel, with many additionals you'd only get from it being digital.
If this is what you came here looking for, then Love at First Sight is indeed what you want.

- Art

As for the art, I feel particularly drawn to the hard lines and the painting style, which reminds me of another VN that I live very much, which is Danganronpa. The animated cutscenes are very well made and looked really cute. I enjoyed it.

- Music

The music in the game feels really nice to the ears and blends well with the ambience. Most of the times, I barely even notice it's presence, as I felt it was part of the scene itself and not just something on the background. My regards to kyou1110 for the great work, though I did like every song of the game.

- Conclusion

Finally, I want to congratulate Ray-K for making this great game. Making a game isn't easy, and making a game by yourself is a hard challenge. But, making a game of this quality by yourself is no short of heroic. People like you and Toby Fox are what I consider heroes in this industry. So, in short, thank you very much.

reviewText: Story with overflowing feelings.

This is a kinetic visual novel about falling in love with a cyclops. I found the characters likable, the story enjoyable, despite being completely predictable, and the art decent. As far as dialogue is concerned, it fit and made sense, yet I still found it slightly dull somehow, with exceptions for all of the puns and reoccuring themes.

In the extras the developer said that he rushed the game for a release date and procrastinated for some time. This is evident in a few places, which are not that horrible, and for which I was surprised for him to site as examples of this. The greatest effect of this though is actually the limitation of certain characters in regards to their presence, the scope of their personalities, the amount of scenes that they are in, their actual appearance in the game, and segments of story that would make sense to include, or would have been nice to have in it.

For some reason despite wondering why the affection object character, Sachi Usui, was depicted as being constantly injured and wearing bandages in screenshots before buying it, I didn't realize how much of a fetish game this is. It contains no nudity or purely sexual content, however Sachi is almost entirely based on fetish fufilment, and fetish interests are very heavy throughout the story. It didn't bother me, however it did catch me off guard. The fetish themes are: cyclops(obviously), scars/injuries, feeding, and protecting/nurturing someone helpless.

Beneath the fetish fulfillment there is a very sweet and endearing story which I will remember and am glad that I experienced.

reviewText:
Love at First Sight is a Romance Visual Novel. It had a development time of 2 months and it clearly shows.

Starting with the positive, the art style is very charming and I loved the design of all the characters. The visuals work very well in favour of the slightly dark yet mostly heart-warming story.

The music is fine, Nothing outstanding in terms of a VN. I wasn't bothered by it and really enjoyed a couple of them despite their short looping time. There isn't much else in terms of sound though, and there is no voice acting.

In terms of the story the primary flaw would have to be the length. Easily the most common complaint at this point. I finished one playthrough on a leisurely pace in 1 hours and 30 minutes. $10 for less than 2 hours of playtime is undeniably a steep price. Other than that, the conflict of the story resolves itself very abruptly. Everything just feels rushed. (Which as the Author has stated, it was)

Personally I enjoyed the experience but I just cannot recommend buying it.

Whilst browsing Steam’s ever-growing visual novel library a new release titled Love at First Sight caught my eye (no pun intended.) Published by the folks at Sekai Project, this high school romance chronicles the blossoming relationship between a shy girl named Sachi Usui and a transfer student called Mamarou. What is so distinguishing about this generic plot I hear you ask? Well, if the game’s picture hasn’t given it away already, Sachi happens to be a Cyclops. The novel’s leading lady was born with a single giant eye and no nose… although that isn’t too odd, as anime characters tend to be lacking in the schnoz department. Love between a human and a monster girl sounds weird to me, but then again what do I know? Monster Musume sells by the bucket load so clearly there is a market out there for geeks who lust after mythological creatures.

OVERVIEW

Our unorthodox tale of love begins with Mamarou bumping into a tearful Sachi. The ocular challenged cutie is feeling low, as a nasty classmate has been tormenting her. Although taken aback by her distinct appearance, Mamarou cannot get Sachi out of his head after their inaugural encounter. Wanting to get to know her better Mamarou begins to meet up with Sachi during recess. After learning that Sachi is an avid reader he begins to woo her with a stockpile of manga before eventually asking her out to a movie. Ah, so that’s what I have been doing wrong. I keep wasting money on flowers and chocolates. Next time I try to court a beauty I will shower her with comics instead.

Love at First Sight’s supporting cast, which you can count on one hand, includes Mamarou’s two best friends. Akemi is a bubbly lass blessed with a motor mouth and is the polar opposite of Tomonori who is much more reserved and sombre. Although likable, Mamarou’s chums are fairly one-dimensional and no I’m not talking about the way they are drawn. The same applies to Rui – the bully who picks on Sachi. Always seen with a scowl on her face, she is presented as a stereotypical troublemaker who preys on the meek. Perhaps the most fleshed out character from the bunch is Sachi’s aunt. She is initially presented as a cold-hearted foster parent, but the novel’s later chapters reveal that her relationship with Sachi is a bit more complex than that.

VERDICT

My rating for Love at First Sight is three stars. It’s a sweet short story brought to life by some striking artwork. Creepy Cute is the artist responsible for creating the novel and it must be said that he lives up to his moniker. Although the graphics have an eerie quality to them he still manages to make the scar covered Sachi look adorable. Even though the story is sold on starring a mono-eyed girl the narrative doesn’t dwell too deeply on Sachi’s looks and reads like a standard teen romance. The only thing weird about the plot is Sachi’s fondness for having her wounds caressed. Is this a clever way of exploring intimacy without resorting to potentially controversial sex scenes? Nah. In the extras section the author openly admits to having a scar fetish.

I would award Love at First Sight a higher score if it weren’t for its steep asking price. The whole thing can be read in just two hours, which isn’t great given that the download costs £7.00. A bit more content would have been nice, especially as Sachi’s final confrontation with Rui feels a tad rushed. Due to time constraints (the whole project was made in a couple of weeks to meet a convention deadline) there are also no branching paths to explore, which hurt the title’s replay value. Those quibbles aside, I still give Love at First Sight a thumbs up. Sachi’s plight should resonate with any readers who suffer from shyness, victims of bullying or anyone who has self-esteem issues pertaining to their physical appearance. Don’t let the cost put you off sampling this treat. If money is an issue “eye” recommend waiting for an inevitable Steam discount.

I first saw this game from a youtuber who does a bunch of anime style games (LostPause aka Noble), he did one episode on it that lasted about 30 or so minutes. I had always wanted him to continue this game but after I played it myself I see why he didn't. This game is simple, the creator even bashes himself for doing this in the afternotes, however I like the game more cause of it. There's no way to fail this game, no way to go down a path you didn't want to take, no way to mess something up. The music, as simplistic as it is, is very nice and catchy and changes somewhat frequently, my most favorite track was when there was drama with Rui. The story is nice and simple, shy girl who has no courage or anything like that and gets bullied, falls in love with a boy who loves her back, she slowly comes out of her shell and even stands up to her bully, an almost cliche type of character development but at least it's there, some games the characters develop so little during hours of gameplay if at all. The only thing that really makes Sachi different is the fact that she's a cyclops, other than that she's no different from anyone else, and as a guy who doesn't judge on appearances I easily see why Ma-Kun (don't want to type his name wrong) was attracted to her, heck I'd date her if she existed. Could this game be longer, yes (note it says I have like 7 hours into the game but I had left it running while did other things) but just because it's short is really only something that an individual has to decides is a good or bad thing. Do you want a game that you play for hours and not get anywhere significant (like most rpg's) or do you want to play a game that's short but be entertained while you play for those few short hours. Is this a perfect game, no but most aren't, I personally would've liked to see Tomo and Akemi get more and more intimate and actually admit how they feel, round 2 of Ms. Bully (Rui) and Ms. Upbeat (Akemi), and even a b*tch slap delivered to Rui via the small scarred hand of Sachi, but those are personal nitpicks, maybe in a continuation of this story and again I would prefer it this style, simple straight to the point, just something that you'll sit down to for an hour or two just to enjoy a nice little romance story without the filler of anime or the images of manga or the complexity of a dating sim (cause let's be honest some of these styles of games can be pretty complex with their choice/path system and all sorts of flags) I would personally rate this a 4/5, it's simple, fun, no hassle, just an overrall carefree game. I recommend this to any fan of anime, manga, and vn's who just want to a nice time and relax.

I wouldn't say I like visual novels, per se. It's more of, I accept it as a platform required to tell stories--and so long as such stories are good, I am fine with them...

However, I could not imagine this story told in any other format. The feelings that the story gave me were quite immersive, as well as beautifully written in a simplistic--yet poetic--style to where I could feel my heart melt with each click of a page. Without spoiler, I will simply say that my heart had sank, stopped, and melted with every emotion under the sun with the help of this wonderous piece.
There are some strange sub-text fields, I'll admit--but having of known several 'quirky' individuals everything is actually all the more authentic. If you've ever enjoyed a heart-felt romance manga or anime, I'd highly reccomend this. Considering most manga are 14.99$, and this only sells for 10$ when not on sale, it's a very grande deal.
